Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding ion-atom collisions in our Galaxy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to improve our understanding of astrophysical objects in our galaxy, it is important to have models of the various processes that occur. Reliable models of X-ray emission due to a process called charge exchange (CX), a collision between an ion and a neutral atom or molecule, are currently of limited availability. Detailed knowledge of the emission spectra due to CX between ions and neutral hydrogen (H) and helium (He) are necessary to predict the resulting X-ray energy dependent spectra which we observe. This research will use explicit CX calculations produced by three astrophysically important collision systems. These calculations will then be benchmarked to measurements done by Dr. Hajime Tanuma's group at Tokyo Metropolitan University. Then, with collaborators at RIKEN, Osaka University, and Kyoto University, the calculated CX spectra will be compared to X-ray observations of the Cygnus Loop, a supernova remnant, using observations from the Japanese telescope Suzaku. This will give us insight into the processes occurring within the Cygnus Loop and other supernova remnants. This project will have a direct impact on advancing our understanding of atomic collisions and X-ray emission in various regions of our galaxy.

CX is a fundamental process in atomic physics which has recently been attributed to the X-ray spectra of various astrophysical environments within our Solar System, supernova remnants, starburst galaxies, and extragalactic cooling flows. When both ions and neutrals are present, CX is one process that can occur which may dominate the ion emission spectra. This research will use explicit CX calculations produced by the astrophysically important collision systems of Fe{15+}, Fe{16+}, and Ne{8+} with He{+} to produce the X-ray emission spectra. This charge exchange data will then be used to model the Cygnus Loop, a supernova remnant that is currently not well understood in the X-ray regime. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our knowledge of the Universe outside of our own atmosphere comes to us in the form of radiation. This radiation is produced by various astrophysical sources over a wide range of wavelengths, from radio to gamma rays. Much of the radiation produced in our own galaxy is not understood well by astronomers and astrophysicists. The focus of this project is on improving our understanding of X-ray radiation produced within our galaxy. The understanding of a supernova remnant, the structure resulting from a star exploding at the end of its life cycle, can give us a deeper understanding of the interstellar medium, the material which fills the space between the stars, and how that medium evolves as the supernova remnant sweeps through this material. By understanding supernova remnants, we are better able to understand why our local region of space got to be as it is. The Cygnus Loop is a well studied, though not well understood, supernova remnant in the Cygnus Constellation. In previous studies, astrophysicists are unable to model the spectrum along the edge of the Cygnus Loop in X-rays, and suggest that a process called Charge Exchange (CX) may contribute a significant portion of the X-rays produced in the environment. In the process of charge exchange, a highly charged ion collides with a neutral target atom, and an electron is transferred between the species resulting in X-rays. Charge exchange calculations were done for the important collision systems of Fe26+ and Fe25+ ions with H, He, H2, and N2 as the neutral target species for various relevant collision energies. The research I performed during the Summer Institute will contribute to the knowledge and understanding of atomic collision processes and has the potential to make significant advances in our understanding of x-ray emission for a variety of astronomical sources from the heliosphere to extended galaxies.

My participation in the Summer Institute will have a direct impact on advancing understanding in atomic collisions while enhancing my training in collision physics. I was given the opportunity to learn about the experiments performed in charge exchange at Tokyo Metropolitan University (TMU). I developed contacts through Prof. Tanuma's group at the at TMU as well as RIKEN, ISAS/JAXA and Osaka University that I've maintained since the Summer Institute, and will hopefully maintain for a long time. This research will eventually be included in modeling packages and allow astronomers whose focus is not on X-ray physics include accurate CX X-ray data in their models.
